Measuring gene expression divergence between gene pairs

Fabricio Almeida-Silva

VIB-UGent Center for Plant Systems Biology, Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium


Yves Van de Peer

VIB-UGent Center for Plant Systems Biology, Ghent University, Ghent, Belgium


Source: vignettes/exdiva_vignette.Rmd
exdiva_vignette.Rmd

Introduction

Gene and genome duplications are important sources of evolutionary innovation. At the transcriptional level, some genes can diverge in expression after duplication, eventually leading to novel functions, while others under stronger selection pressures preserve expression levels. To understand the evolution of gene expression following duplication, we developed exdiva, a package that provides users with a set of metrics to compute expression divergence between duplicate pairs. exdiva integrates with the Bioconductor ecosystem by accepting as input core S4 classes, including SummarizedExperiment objects (for bulk RNA-seq data), SingleCellExperiment objects (for single-cell RNA-seq data), and SpatialExperiment objects (for spatial transcriptomics data).

Installation

You can install exdiva from Bioconductor with the following code:

if(!requireNamespace("BiocManager", quietly = TRUE)) {
    install.packages("BiocManager")
}

BiocManager::install("exdiva")

## Check that you have a valid Bioconductor installation
BiocManager::valid()

Then, you can load the package:

library(exdiva)

We will also load other required packages to use in this vignette.

library(SummarizedExperiment)
set.seed(123) # for reproducibility

Data description

In this vignette, we will use data from a publicly available experiment (SRA Study ID: SRP213876) in which authors investigated seed germination in A. thaliana seeds exposed to red and far-red light (Tognacca et al. 2019). Expression data in transcripts per million (TPM) were obtained from refine.bio and stored in a SummarizedExperiment object. Let’s first take a look at them.

# Load expression data
data(ath_se)

# Show `SummarizedExperiment` object
ath_se
#> class: SummarizedExperiment 
#> dim: 22545 6 
#> metadata(0):
#> assays(1): TPM
#> rownames(22545): AT1G01010 AT1G01020 ... ATMG01310 ATMG01410
#> rowData names(0):
#> colnames(6): SRR9659514 SRR9659515 ... SRR9659518 SRR9659519
#> colData names(3): experiment tissue treatment

# Take a look at assay and colData slots
assay(ath_se) |> head()
#>           SRR9659514 SRR9659515 SRR9659516 SRR9659517 SRR9659518 SRR9659519
#> AT1G01010   77.71092   56.03711   76.01148   88.05801   70.60007   85.64420
#> AT1G01020  460.21158  417.35464  464.21402  247.83946  360.69977  303.03580
#> AT1G01030   49.03193   27.52164   46.13850   15.80170   21.04727   38.64825
#> AT1G01040  564.81950  380.74603  750.09094  572.19684  863.37067  687.85156
#> AT1G01050  605.36630  526.64270  666.37146  477.44717  684.85050  637.83575
#> AT1G01060  731.03310  603.77970  898.30460  103.11177  149.65310  123.45633
colData(ath_se)
#> DataFrame with 6 rows and 3 columns
#>             experiment      tissue   treatment
#>            <character> <character> <character>
#> SRR9659514   SRP213876       seeds         Red
#> SRR9659515   SRP213876       seeds         Red
#> SRR9659516   SRP213876       seeds         Red
#> SRR9659517   SRP213876       seeds     Far-red
#> SRR9659518   SRP213876       seeds     Far-red
#> SRR9659519   SRP213876       seeds     Far-red

The entire set of duplicated gene pairs in the A. thaliana genome was obtained with the Bioconductor package doubletrouble (Almeida-Silva and Van de Peer 2024). Data are stored in a data frame with 3 columns as below:

# Load data
data(ath_dups)

# Take a look at the first rows of the data frame
head(ath_dups)
#>        dup1      dup2 type
#> 1 AT2G17930 AT4G36080   SD
#> 2 AT1G03060 AT4G02660   SD
#> 3 AT2G45540 AT3G60920   SD
#> 4 ATCG01280 ATCG00860   SD
#> 5 AT3G28770 AT5G39870   SD
#> 6 AT1G05570 AT2G31960   SD

To demonstrate metrics that require gene coexpression networks, we used BioNERO to infer a signed coexpression network with data from Wan et al. (2019), available on refine.bio. Then, we saved the data frame of module assignment and module eigengenes in the objects below.

# Load and show data frame of genes per module
data(genes_and_modules)
head(genes_and_modules)
#>       Genes        Modules
#> 1 AT1G01040         orange
#> 2 AT1G01050    greenyellow
#> 3 AT1G01060    darkorange2
#> 4 AT1G01080    lightyellow
#> 5 AT1G01090    darkorange2
#> 6 AT1G01100 darkolivegreen

# Load and show data frame of module eigengenes
data(ME)
head(ME)
#>            MEdarkmagenta     MEplum2 MEdarkolivegreen MEgreenyellow     MEplum1

#> SRR9331157    0.03272060 -0.03500161      0.007757575   -0.06353141 -0.04264297

Calculating expression divergence

exdiva offers different metrics of expression divergence, namely:

  1. Spearman correlations between gene pairs;
  2. The τ\tau index of tissue specificity;
  3. Co-occurrence in coexpression modules;
  4. Distance between module eigengenes.

Metric 1: Spearman correlations between gene pairs

To calculate correlations between gene pairs, you will use the function calculate_cor(), which takes as input an object of class SummarizedExperiment, SingleCellExperiment, or SpatialExperiment.

# Calculate Spearman correlations between gene pairs
dup10 <- ath_dups[1:10, ] # subset first 10 pairs for demonstration purposes
cor_df <- calculate_cor(ath_se, dup10)

# Show output
cor_df
#>         dup1      dup2 type         cor
#> 1  AT2G17930 AT4G36080   SD  0.65714286
#> 2  AT1G03060 AT4G02660   SD  0.94285714
#> 3  AT2G45540 AT3G60920   SD  0.25714286
#> 4  ATCG01280 ATCG00860   SD          NA
#> 5  AT3G28770 AT5G39870   SD          NA
#> 6  AT1G05570 AT2G31960   SD  0.31428571
#> 7  AT3G60860 AT1G01960   SD  0.71428571
#> 8  ATCG01130 ATCG01000   SD          NA
#> 9  AT2G33240 AT1G04600   SD -0.02857143
#> 10 AT1G79000 AT3G12980   SD  0.88571429

Metric 2: The τ\tau index of tissue specificity

The τ\tau index of tissue specificity ranges from 0 to 1, with values close to 0 indicating a broader expression profile across tissues, and values close to 1 indicating a more tissue-specific profile. To calculate τ\tau, we need a matrix of gene expression aggregated to tissue level, with genes in rows and tissue names in columns. This can be obtained from a SummarizedExperiment object with the function aggregate_to_tissue(), which calculates the median (or mean) gene expression per tissue using a user-defined variable in the colData slot. However, since we have samples from a single tissue only, we will simulate a two-tissue data set by modifying our colData variable tissue:

# Change tissue name in half of the samples
ath_se$tissue[1:3] <- "leaf"
colData(ath_se)
#> DataFrame with 6 rows and 3 columns
#>             experiment      tissue   treatment
#>            <character> <character> <character>
#> SRR9659514   SRP213876        leaf         Red
#> SRR9659515   SRP213876        leaf         Red
#> SRR9659516   SRP213876        leaf         Red
#> SRR9659517   SRP213876       seeds     Far-red
#> SRR9659518   SRP213876       seeds     Far-red
#> SRR9659519   SRP213876       seeds     Far-red

# Get median expression per tissue using "tissue" variable in colData
aexp <- aggregate_to_tissue(ath_se, "tissue")

head(aexp)
#>                leaf     seeds
#> AT1G01010  76.01148  85.64420
#> AT1G01020 460.21158 303.03580
#> AT1G01030  46.13850  21.04727
#> AT1G01040 564.81950 687.85156
#> AT1G01050 605.36630 637.83575
#> AT1G01060 731.03310 123.45633

Now that we have a matrix of gene expression per tissue, we can use the function calculate_tau(). Besides, calculating τ\tau, this function classifies genes into one of four expression-based categories:

  1. Null: Expression <1 TPM in all tissues.
  2. Weak: Expression <5 TPM in all tissues.
  3. Broad: τ\tau <0.85.
  4. Specific: τ\tau >= 0.85.
# Calculate tau index of tissue specificity
tau_df <- calculate_tau(aexp)

head(tau_df)
#>        gene         tau class
#> 1 AT1G01010 0.026414297 Broad
#> 2 AT1G01020 0.067936283 Broad
#> 3 AT1G01030 0.197218638 Broad
#> 4 AT1G01040 0.030107101 Broad
#> 5 AT1G01050 0.008075227 Broad
#> 6 AT1G01060 0.268635181 Broad

Then, this data frame with τ\tau indices per gene can be used to compare expression profiles of duplicated gene pairs using the function compare_tau() as follows:

# Compare tau indices among duplicated gene pairs
tau_comp <- compare_tau(tau_df, ath_dups)

head(tau_comp)
#>        dup1      dup2 type    tau_dup1 class_dup1   tau_dup2 class_dup2
#> 1 AT4G01550 AT1G01010   DD 0.058046902      Broad 0.02641430      Broad
#> 2 AT1G02220 AT1G01010   DD 0.404289662      Broad 0.02641430      Broad
#> 3 AT4G01510 AT1G01020   DD 0.162417251      Broad 0.06793628      Broad
#> 4 AT5G45150 AT1G01040   DD 0.003416496      Broad 0.03010710      Broad
#> 5 AT4G15417 AT1G01040   DD 1.000000000       Weak 0.03010710      Broad
#> 6 AT1G35530 AT1G01040   DD 0.143371321      Broad 0.03010710      Broad
#>     tau_diff class_preserved
#> 1 0.03163261            TRUE
#> 2 0.37787537            TRUE
#> 3 0.09448097            TRUE
#> 4 0.02669061            TRUE
#> 5 0.96989290           FALSE
#> 6 0.11326422            TRUE

The column tau_diff indicates the absolute difference in τ\tau indices between gene pairs, and the column class_preserved indicates whether expression-based classes are the same in both members of a gene pair.

Metric 3: Co-occurrence in coexpression modules

Gene coexpression networks can be used to identify cluster of genes with very similar expression profiles across samples, which are termed coexpression modules. Here, exdiva uses such information to compare module assignment for genes in a pair and check if they are in the same module (and thus, have similar expression profiles) or in different modules. This can be done with the function compare_coex_modules().

# Compare module assignment between duplicate pairs
mod_comp <- compare_coex_modules(ath_dups, genes_and_modules)

head(mod_comp)
#>        dup1      dup2 type module_dup1 module_dup2 module_preservation
#> 1 AT1G02220 AT1G01010   DD        <NA>        <NA>         both_absent
#> 2 AT4G01550 AT1G01010   DD        <NA>        <NA>         both_absent
#> 3 AT4G01510 AT1G01020   DD        <NA>        <NA>         both_absent
#> 4 AT4G15417 AT1G01040   DD        <NA>      orange          one_absent
#> 5 AT1G35530 AT1G01040   DD        <NA>      orange          one_absent
#> 6 AT5G45150 AT1G01040   DD        <NA>      orange          one_absent

The variable module_preservation summarizes results for each gene pair in a factor with the following levels:

  1. preserved: Both genes are in the same module.
  2. diverged: Genes are in different modules.
  3. one_absent: One gene in the pair is not present in any module. This could be because the gene is not present in the input expression data (due to low or no expression), or because the module detection algorithm could not assign the gene to any module.
  4. both_absent: Both genes are not present in any module.

To get the frequency of gene pairs in each category, you can use:

# Get frequency of gene pairs for each category
table(mod_comp$module_preservation)
#> 
#>   preserved    diverged  one_absent both_absent 
#>         998        2924       13223       30340

Metric 4: Distance between module eigengenes

Co-occurrence in coexpression modules is binary: genes are either in the same module or not. However, genes can be in different, but (somewhat) similar modules, or in completely different modules. In that case, we need a way of comparing distance between modules. Here, we do so by calculating correlations between module eigengenes (i.e., the first principal component of each module, which describes most of the variation). This can be done with the function compare_coex_me(). Importantly, such comparison is only made for genes in the diverged category (see previous section for details).

# Compare module eigengenes for diverged duplicate pairs
me_comp <- compare_coex_me(mod_comp, ME)

head(me_comp)
#>        dup1      dup2 type      ME_cor
#> 1 AT2G24270 AT1G79440   DD  0.06105458
#> 2 AT2G33990 AT5G03040 dTRD -0.56880204
#> 3 AT2G38400 AT5G46180   DD -0.56880204
#> 4 AT5G55700 AT3G23920   DD -0.56880204
#> 5 AT4G39660 AT1G80600   DD -0.56880204
#> 6 AT2G33990 AT3G22190 dTRD -0.56880204

References

Almeida-Silva, Fabricio, and Yves Van de Peer. 2024. “Doubletrouble: An r/Bioconductor Package for the Identification, Classification, and Analysis of Gene and Genome Duplications.” bioRxiv, 2024–02.
Tognacca, Rocı́o Soledad, Lucas Servi, Carlos Esteban Hernando, Maite Saura-Sanchez, Marcelo Javier Yanovsky, Ezequiel Petrillo, and Javier Francisco Botto. 2019. “Alternative Splicing Regulation During Light-Induced Germination of Arabidopsis Thaliana Seeds.” Frontiers in Plant Science 10: 468265.
Wan, Wei-Lin, Lisha Zhang, Rory Pruitt, Maricris Zaidem, Rik Brugman, Xiyu Ma, Elzbieta Krol, et al. 2019. “Comparing Arabidopsis Receptor Kinase and Receptor Protein-Mediated Immune Signaling Reveals BIK1-Dependent Differences.” New Phytologist 221 (4): 2080–95.
